answers: the Count [or the father of Miss Julie]
kills her bird [accept decapitates or cuts off the head or synonyms in place of "kills"; accept canary or Serena in place of "bird"] <Droge>
parts: Identify this unnamed and unseen character, the employer of the cook Christine. His arrival at the end of the play ends the plans of two characters to start a hotel together.
This Swedish author wrote the play Miss Julie.
Late in Miss Julie, while the valet Jean tries to persuade Miss Julie to come away with him, he engages in what violent action directed against a companion of Julie's?

answers: Frances "Fanny" Crosby [or Frances Jane van Alstyne] <Cheyne>
parts: Give the English title or first line of this hymn, still sung today even though it was written in 1529. This hymn proclaims that the Lord is "a bulwark never failing" and is "our helper… amid the flood of mortal ills prevailing."
"A Mighty Fortress Is Our God" was written by this Protestant leader and author of the Ninety-five Theses.

Despite her blindness, this woman wrote more than 8,000 hymns, including such standards as "Blessed Assurance" and "To God Be the Glory." Some hymnals gave her aliases rather than credit her so many times for songs.
Name this cosmological period during which the first stars and galaxies formed. "Holes" in the 21-centimeter background indicate the stripping of electrons from hydrogen during this period.
Reionization occurred approximately 400 million years after this other event that marked the creation of all of the matter in the universe.

The presence of this effect in the spectra of observed quasars at around z-equals-6 provides evidence for the epoch of reionization. In this effect, the flux drops to zero at wavelengths below the Lyman-alpha peak.

answers: the Duke of Wellington [or Arthur Wellesley]
parts: Foreign Secretary George Canning engaged in what kind of event in 1809 at Putney Heath, which resulted in him suffering a thigh wound?
The Earl of Winchilsea memorably fought a duel with this man, a Prime Minister better known for defeating Napoleon at Waterloo.
After a duel in which his opponent died, this Irish leader known as the "Liberator" refused to fight another duel. He held "Monster Meetings" calling for the repeal of the Act of Union.
Name this 1935 novel in which the villainous President Buzz Windrip runs the fascist-style "Corpo" government.
It Can't Happen Here was written by this author whose other satirical books include Main Street and Arrowsmith.
This other novel about a dystopian government features the "Oligarchy" building the poverty-ridden city of Asgard. This book features a resistance whose members include Ernest and Avis Everhard.

answers: deceptive cadence [accept false cadence, interrupted cadence, or false close; prompt on evaded cadence or weak cadence] <Lifshitz>
parts: Name this late Romantic composer who quoted the "Dies Irae" in his Isle for the Dead and wrote a difficult Piano Concerto No. 3.

The last of Rachmaninoff's 14 Romances, Opus 34, is one of these wordless songs in C-sharp minor. Fauré and Messiaen (mess-YAWN) wrote études of this type, and one by Ravel is in the form of a habanera.

In Rachmaninoff's Vocalise, the soprano sings her long last note over this type of cadence, one of which opens Beethoven's Les Adieux (lay zah-DYUH). In this type of "irregular resolution," a 5 chord surprisingly resolves up to a 6 chord instead of the tonic; it's often used to extend a phrase or create a "one more time" effect.

answers: Northern Ireland [or Tuaisceart Éireann; prompt on the United Kingdom; prompt on U.K.; do not accept or prompt on "Ireland" or "Republic of Ireland"]
parts: Name this country whose Democratic Unionist Party and its allies failed to win a majority for the first time ever in that 2017 election.
Martin McGuinness, a member of this party, was the Deputy First Minister who resigned in 2017. McGuinness is a member of this party, the largest nationalist party in the Northern Ireland assembly.

The founder of the Democratic Unionist Party, Ian Paisley, once shouted "I denounce you as the Antichrist" at this religious leader. Born Karol Wojtyla in Poland, this man was succeeded by Benedict XVI.

answers: Marie Antoinette [or Maria Antonia Josepha Johanna]
Louise Elisabeth Vigée le Brun (vee-JAY luh BRUN) [or Madame Lebrun] <Bentley>
parts: Name this French artist who adopted unusual poses such as yawning in his self-portraits. A self-portrait in which he points at the viewer has become an Internet meme.
Ducreux painted a portrait of this woman prior to her marriage. Jacques-Louis David sketched this queen on her way to the guillotine.

This female artist made several sympathetic portraits of Marie Antoinette, including one in which her son lifts the cover of a cradle of a dead relative. She depicted Lord Nelson's mistress, Lady Hamilton, as a Bacchante (buh-KONT) holding a tambourine.

answers: Quintus Fabius Maximus Verrucosus [or the Fabian strategy]
sling [or shepherd's sling; do not accept "slingshot"] <Cheyne>
parts: Name this Roman leader or his namesake strategy that he employed after the Battle of Lake Trasimene. His strategy involved wearing down an opponent and avoiding frontal assaults and decisive battles, which annoyed the public.
The Fabian strategy was used when Rome fought this city in the Punic Wars.

After abandoning the Fabian strategy, the Romans were crushed at the Battle of Cannae, in which Carthage employed numerous fighters from the Balearic Islands who were skilled with this weapon. Ancient authors were impressed with this weapon's range and supposedly armor-piercing power.

answers: Mormonism; or LDS; or Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]
Unification Church [or Family Federation for World Peace and Unification; or the Holy Spirit Association for the Unification of World Christianity; or Unificationism; prompt on Moonies] <Cheyne>
parts: In his book Lights Out, Koppel noted that followers of this religion were well-equipped to survive a cyberattack on America's power grids. He described the storehouses of supplies that the heads of this religion have created in Utah.
In a contentious 1992 interview, Koppel grilled David Miscavige, a prominent leader in this religion, who made his first and to-date only live TV appearance on Koppel's program.

In 1994, Koppel apologized for using a potentially pejorative term to refer to followers of this religion. Its scripture is called the Exposition of the Divine Principle, and it held large public gatherings in the 1970s in New York.

answers: Necho [or Nekau; or Neku; or Nechoh; or Nikuu]
parts: Give the name of the Egyptian Pharaoh, the second with this name, who also ordered an expedition of Phoenicians, which supposedly sailed around Africa in three years.
Necho II also attempted to build a canal from the Nile to the Red Sea, a precursor of sorts to this modern, artificial waterway connecting the Mediterranean and Red Seas.
The Phoenician story comes to readers from this historian, whose knowledge of Egypt has been questioned, as has his claim that giant ants could be found in India.

answers: pale AND wan [accept in either order; do not accept any other answers] <Collins>
parts: Name this group of 17th-century British poets including Richard Lovelace, Thomas Carew, and Sir John Suckling.
While Lovelace was in one of these locations, he wrote a poem to Althea that contains the line, "Stone walls do not [one of these places] make / nor iron bars a cage."
John Suckling's play Aglaura is the original source of a poem that opens with the speaker asking a "fond lover" why he has these two synonymous qualities.

answers: "I Am the Very Model of a Modern Major-General" [or the Major-General; or Stanley]
the square of the hypotenuse [prompt on hypotenuse] <Cheyne>
parts: Name either this song or the character who sings this song from The Pirates of Penzance. The singer of this song knows the kings of England and quotes "the fights historical."
The Pirates of Penzance is a comic opera by W. S. Gilbert and this composer.
In the first stanza of the song, the Major-General says that he has many cheerful facts about this mathematical concept, which he rhymes with "a lot of news."

answers: having odd order [accept "size" or "number of elements" in place of "order"]
parts: Identify this property of groups. The Feit–Thompson Theorem, whose proof took up an entire issue of the Pacific Journal of Mathematics, showed that all groups with this property are solvable.

The Feit–Thompson theorem implies that all groups of odd order have one of this type of subgroup, whose left and right cosets are equal. In three-dimensional geometry, this adjective describes vectors that are perpendicular to a surface or a plane at a point.

Solvable groups are used in the theory of this kind of function, which can always be solved in radicals if their degree is four or lower. These functions consist of sums of powers of a variable multiplied by coefficients.
Identify these configurations of a thermodynamic system. The entropy is proportional to the log of the number of these configurations.
That equation for the entropy of a system was formulated by this man, who co-names a law of blackbody radiation with Josef Stefan.
This hypothesis says that all microstates are equally probable over a sufficiently long time. The Fermi–Pasta–Ulam (OO-lom) experiment showed that this hypothesis did not hold for a vibrating string.

answers: Aegina [or Aigina; or Oinone; or Aphaia]
parts: Zeus once seduced a nymph of this name in the form of an eagle, and turned her into a vegetation goddess by burying her to escape Hera's wrath. The muse of comedy and the Grace other than Aglaea and Euphrosyne share this name.
Zeus also pulled the eagle trick with this nymph and left her on the island named for her. Their son was Achilles's grandfather Aeacus, who prayed for the creation of the Myrmidons.
Zeus more famously disguised himself as a swan to get the attention of this queen of Sparta, resulting in the hatching of the Dioskouroi, Clytemnestra, and Helen.
Name this man who fatally shot a youth in Sanford, Florida. He argued self-defense and was acquitted in 2013.
Zimmerman called this politician "an ignorant baboon." This father of Sasha and Malia infamously noted if he had a son, he would look like the youth Zimmerman killed, Trayvon Martin.

Another racial incident during the Obama presidency involved the President hosting a "beer summit" between Sgt. James Crowley and this African-American professor arrested in 2009 after neighbors thought he was trying to break into his own home.
Name these blood-sucking arachnids that transmit the pathogens responsible for Rocky Mountain spotted fever and Lyme disease.
Rocky Mountain spotted fever is caused by a member of this genus of bacteria. Typhus develops from infection with other species in this genus.

Another tick-borne disease, tularemia, is also named for a fever attributed to contact with this mammal. A namesake hemorrhagic disease virus and myxoma virus have been used to control certain populations of this animal.

answers: Christian [accept but DO NOT REVEAL the pilgrim]
The Pilgrim's Progress from This World, to That Which Is to Come
parts: Name or describe this character who battles the demon Apollyon, is arrested at Vanity Fair, and ultimately arrives at the Celestial City.
Christian is the protagonist of this John Bunyan novel that is an allegory for the Christian lifestyle.
The second part of Pilgrim's Progress features the character of Mercy, four youths, and this other person making the same journey as Christian. Name or describe this character.

answers: saving [or paradox of saving; or paradox of thrift]
supply AND demand [accept in either order] <Droge>
parts: Name these things, two popular American examples of which were produced by Lorie Tarshis and Paul Samuelson after World War II.
A paradox discussed in Samuelson's textbook Economics states that individuals performing this action may lead to lower aggregate demand and thus less of this action on a national level.

The fifth book of Alfred Marshall's Principles of Economics discusses formal representations of these two contrasting economic concepts. The quantities specified by these two concepts will balance at the market clearing price.
Name this genre, whose authors included Isaac Asimov, the author of "Nightfall."
This golden age author wrote the novel Starship Troopers and a book about Valentine Michael Smith, a human raised on Mars, titled Stranger in a Strange Land.

In this science fiction novel by Walter Miller, the cycle of nuclear war, the destruction of knowledge, and the struggle of mankind to preserve what it knows is played out cyclically over the course of three sections titled after Latin phrases.
